metadata.case_name: Gurusidhwaswami v. Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha

facts.text: On November 13, 1887, Gurusidhwaswami, the then head of Murusavirmath, granted a permanent lease of a tract of land (R. No. 34) to Pradhanappa at rent of Rs. 50 per annum for first six years and thereafter Rs. 25 annually.
On June 19, 1892, Pradhanappa sold a portion of the leasehold property (Schedule 1b to the plaint) to Bharamappa.
In 1897, Gurusidhwaswami died and was succeeded by Gangadhar Swami, who did not repudiate the lease and accepted rents.
In April 1905, another part of the land (Schedule 1a to the plaint) was sold in execution of a decree against Pradhanappa's heirs to Kadayya, who sold it to Bharamappa.
On April 8, 1910, Bharamappa gifted the entire premises (Schedules 1a and 1b) to Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha for building a school for Jain students.
On August 31, 1920, Gangadhar Swami died; affairs managed by committee.
On November 25, 1925, present plaintiff Gurusidhwaswami became head of the Math.

On August 27, 1932, plaintiff instituted Suit No. 80 of 1932 against heirs of Bharamappa for possession, alleging lease invalid without legal necessity; Jain Sabha impleaded as defendant No. 23 under wrong name.

Suit No. 80/1932 dismissed by trial judge; on appeal, Bombay High Court reversed on November 26, 1942, granting possession against all defendants except defendant No. 23 (Jain Sabha) due to misdescription.
On December 3, 1943, plaintiff filed present suit (Special Civil Suit No. 21 of 1944) against Jain Sabha for possession, alleging original lease invalid without legal necessity.
Trial court (Civil Judge, Hubli, December 17, 1945) held lease invalid but suit barred by limitation under Article 134-B Limitation Act; suit dismissed.
Bombay High Court (Bavdekar and Dixit JJ., October 19, 1949) affirmed dismissal on limitation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the original permanent lease was supported by legal necessity.
Whether the plaintiff's suit is barred by limitation under Article 134-B of the Indian Limitation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Decree for ejectment in earlier suit of 1932 against heirs of Bharamappa binds present defendant as sub-lessee.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principle that decree against lessee binds sub-lessee

petitioner_arguments.text: Limitation saved by Section 10 of Indian Limitation Act.
Lease not for valuable consideration as rent inadequate.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit barred by limitation under Article 134-B from death of previous Mahant in 1920.

court_reasoning.text: Even if previous decree binds sub-lessee, present suit barred under Section 47 CPC; but 1932 suit not by landlord against tenant, and Jain Sabha not sub-lessee but absolute gift donee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1932 suit was to recover Math property improperly alienated, treating defendants as trespassers post-Mahant's death; gift deed not sub-lease.

court_reasoning.text: Section 10 inapplicable as defendant not assign without valuable consideration; lease was for valuable consideration despite low rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Valuable consideration not synonymous with adequate consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Trial court found no legal necessity for lease, but limitation bars suit.

holdings.text: Suit governed by Article 134-B Limitation Act; 12 years from previous Mahant's death in 1920.
Previous decree does not bind defendant as not sub-lessee and suit not landlord-tenant eviction.
Section 10 Limitation Act does not apply as transfer for valuable consideration.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs limitation period for suit to recover Math property; Section 10 exception for valuable consideration applies

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Court may treat suit as execution; bars fresh suit if previous decree binds

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirming High Court and trial court decrees dismissing the suit as barred by limitation under Article 134-B from 1920.

key_quotes.text: It may be unfortunate that by reason of a pure misdescription, the earlier suit was dismissed against the Jain Sabha, but that is altogether irrelevant for our present purpose.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dismisses reliance on previous suit's effect due to misjoinder

key_quotes.text: The expression valuable consideration has a well known connotation in law and it is not synonymous with adequate consideration.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that low rent means no valuable consideration for Section 10
